required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on June 04, 2014
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Laser Versus Ultrasound Lithotripsy in Percutaneous Nephrolithotomy for Staghorn Stones
clinical_study.official_title: Laser Versus Ultrasound Lithotripsy in Percutaneous Nephrolithotomy for Staghorn Stones

brief_summary.textblock: This study will be conducted to compare the results of Laser and ultrasound lithotripsy in disintegration of staghorn stones during percutaneous nephrolithotomy.

detailed_description.textblock:
Patients with complete staghorn stones who are eligible to percutaneous nephrolithotomy (PNL) will be randomized between two groups.
Group 1: will undergo Laser lithotripsy during PNL Group 2: will undergo ultrasound lithotripsy during PNL

clinical_study.study_design: Allocation: Randomized, Endpoint Classification: Safety/Efficacy Study, Intervention Model: Parallel Assignment, Masking: Open Label, Primary Purpose: Treatment

primary_outcome.measure: Assessment of the impact of lithotripsy device on operative time
primary_outcome.time_frame: Time needed to complete the procedure for each patient, an expected average of 3 hours

primary_outcome.measure: Assessment of the impact of lithotripsy device on intraoperative complications
primary_outcome.time_frame: participants will be assessed for the duration of surgery, an expected average of 3 hours

secondary_outcome.time_frame: participants will be followed for the duration of hospital stay, an expected average of 5 days
secondary_outcome.description: Complications will be graded according to modified Clavien grading system
The stone free rate will be evaluated with non-contrast CT 3 months after PNL

intervention.description: Patients will undergo laser lithotripsy durin PNL
Patients will undergo ultrasound lithotripsy during PNL

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
1. Complete staghorn stones (filling the renal pelvis and branching to 3 major calyces
2. Age: 18-70 years
Exclusion Criteria:
1. Congenital renal anomalies such as horse shoe kidney.
2. Contraindications to PNL such as bleeding tendency and uncontrolled hypertension.
3. Associated pathological features requiring open intervention such as UPJO
4. Partial staghorn stones (filling the renal pelvis and branching to 2 major calyces)
5. Giant staghorn stone (very large staghorn stone that branch and re-branch in hugely dilated calyceal system)
